title: 105_s124
content: The Act titled "National Research Investment Act of 1997" is established for research purposes. Congress finds that in fiscal year 1965, 5.7 percent of the Federal budget was spent on nondefense research and development activities. By fiscal year 1997, this percentage decreased to 1.9 percent, a 67 percent reduction from 1965. Additionally, from fiscal year 1992 to 1995, Federal research funding decreased each year in real dollars. The Act aims to double Federal funding for basic science and medical research over a 10-year period to $65 billion in fiscal year 2007. It emphasizes the importance of increased investment in research to maintain the US as a global technological leader. The Act aims to double Federal funding for basic science and medical research to $65 billion by 2007. It prioritizes science and technology in the Federal budget, invests in research activities, enhances quality of life, and ensures US leadership in science and medicine. The Act prioritizes science and technology in the Federal budget and aims to double Federal funding for basic science and medical research to $65 billion by 2007. SEC. 3 authorizes appropriations. The term "funds for covered research and development" includes appropriations for various agencies like the National Science Foundation, NASA, NOAA, NIST, and NIH. The curr_chunk discusses appropriations for basic science or medical research by various federal agencies including the Centers for Disease Control, Department of Energy, Department of Agriculture, Department of Veterans Affairs, Smithsonian Institution, Department of Education, and Environmental Protection Agency. Authorization of appropriations is subject to limitations. For covered research and development, authorized appropriations are as follows: $35,750,000,000 for fiscal year 1998, $39,000,000,000 for fiscal year 1999, $42,250,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, and $45,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, with specific allocations for the National Institutes of Health. For fiscal years 2001 to 2004, authorized appropriations are as follows: $45,500,000,000 for 2001, $48,750,000,000 for 2002, $52,000,000,000 for 2003, and $55,250,000,000 for 2004, with specific allocations for the National Institutes of Health. For fiscal years 2005 to 2007, authorized appropriations for Human Services are $58.5 billion for 2005, $61.75 billion for 2006, and $65 billion for 2007, with specific allocations for the National Institutes of Health. The appropriate officials must prioritize basic scientific research for public access, with funds only for precompetitive technology research. A peer review system must be used for allocating funds. SEC. 4. COMPLIANCE WITH DISCRETIONARY CAPS. No funds under this Act can exceed discretionary spending caps in the budget resolution.
